text: 2013/Jan. Cellared. Purchased in Chicago 3 months fresh. Nice strong carbonation noise on breaking the seal. I was worried it was going to spray all over the place. Ruby with just slight brown hues. Short, ample small bubble off white head with mild lacing. Lots of fast moving carbonation. This has stood up exceptionally. Nose is heavy with raspberry, green leaves, and yeast. Lots of apple tart, raspberry, and a background nutty toast on the palate. Its obviously a sour, so the nuances of acid, and fruit. Traces of wood, whiff of smoke. Faint charred sugars in the background, likely from contact with hot surfaces during the boil. Faint menthol/mint in the finish, with notes of black tea. Excellent.
Bottle best before 2009 sampled 2017. Cherry fruit and mild lactic aroma. Very cloudy light brown color. Fruity and light acidic taste with a small sweetness.

Bottle. 2005 vintage. Light hazy brown liquid with small white head. Aroma of lemon, apple skin, balsamic, port wine, raisins and dried fruit. Taste is light sweet and medium sour with notes of lemon, port wine, raisins and apple skin. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Really nice, very well aged.
Bottle form importer. nice sourness vintage edition, dark malts works well with sour.

750 ml bottle shared. Hazy reddish brown appearance with a small tan head. Aroma of sour funk, light oak, mild caramel malt and a mild sweetness. Medium body with a light watery feel. Hints of a vanilla and dark fruits round things out. Nicely balanced but pricey.

Bomber from Crafted in Haymarket, VA
Aroma: sour cherries, bread, hay, woody
Appearance: hazy amber with an off-white head
Taste: medium sourness, light sweetness, 
Palate: light body, slick feel, average carbonation, dry finish

Excellent

Dark amber/cider color; Medium body; Aroma of woody malt, yeast, sour fruit, & some vanilla/caramel; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, oak, sour dark fruit (notably cherries), some vinegar, and spice; Finish is dry & sour/tart; Very nicely balanced; Simply well done - very good overall.

ASPETTO: marrone mogano scuro, abbastanza limpido, schiuma beige, abbondante, fine e persistente. AROMA: acetoso, aceto balsamico, frutti rossi, legnoso e, stranamente, intonaco! GUSTO: attacca con un acetico deciso, poco fruttato. Sentori legnosi, vinosi, leggerissimo luppolato alla fine. Corpo leggero, carbonizzazione molto bassa (un po troppo). Fino ad ora la migliore sour italiana, ma ne ho assaggiate di più complesse, soprattutto del Belgio.
Caoba con espuma marfil. Aromas de frutos rojos, cereza. Cuerpo ligero, con sabor intenso de fruto rojo y final seco con regusto ferroso.

Bouteille. Batch #20. Liquide ambré dont la teinte nest pas clairement définie. Est-ce brun? Rouge? Cest trouble et flou. Tête très timide qui tient étonnement bien la route. Arômes sucrés de caramel, de bois, de vanille, de gâteau. Je suis plus dans la pâtisserie que dans le fruit. Curieux mélange de sucreries et de bois qui semble fonctionner. Cest cet aspect terreux qui me déplaît et me rebute. Beaucoup déléments à la fois qui me semblent mal structurés. Saveurs off en bouche. Le sucre sest amoindri et les notes dacétone prennent le dessus. Parmi ces saveurs puissantes de raisin, de caramel chauffé et de vinaigre blanc, se situent des saveurs off aussi perturbantes que les arômes. De deux choses lune: soit la bouteille a mal évolué, soit le brasseur a cherché à trop en mettre dans un même breuvage.
750 ml bottle shared. Clear amber with a thin beige head. Aroma is vinous, dark berry, some funk. Taste has a lot of nutty, caramel notes. Not much tartness. Medium body and medium carbonation.
Bottle. Thanks Tohara-san. Aroma is booze, plastic, grapes and leather. Taste is alright, oaky, fruit and sweetness, light sourness, bit of funk.

On tap @ arrogant soour festival 2016. Ramato opalescente, schiuma beige fine e persistente. Aroma intenso fruttato, amarene, acete di mele, caramello, lieve tostatura. Abboccato, dolciastro da caramello, poi acido importante, tendente al lattico. Corposa, carbonatazione media, Astringente su gengive. Equilibrata ed armonica.
Pours dark amber with a good head. Aroma is dank a bit sweet sour cellar dusty fruity. Flavor is similar.
Aroma is sour/tart fruit, malts and a hint of milk/Worcestershire sauce funk. The flavor is raspberries/cherries, malts, fruit, mild sour/sweet funk and a tart/earthy/very slightly milky finish.
Pours a reddish brown color. Aromas of dark fruit, yeast, and a touch of wood. Flavor is sour cherries, yeast, wood, and a couple of sweet tarts.

Draft at Slow Boat. This is a cool spot. Deep dark reddish pour. Small head, some lacing. Oak, leather, well-balanced balsamic tartness and malty, lightly sweet backing. After acclimating over the first few sips, this just gets more and more delicious.

On tap at the Modern Times Festival of Funk. It pours an amber color with an off white head. The aroma has sour berries with some sweet tarts. The flavor has a good balance of fruity, berry-like tartness and sweeter fruit flavors. Clean. Good stuff.

2006 bottle. Aroma is red wine, cherry skins, and light vinegar. Tastes like red wine and cardboard. Probably shouldve opened this a bit sooner. Dry finish. Im gonna look for a fresher bottle to try again some time.

A small taste from a friend (bottle) @ Il Birrificio. Pours clear deep amber with a low head. Aroma is sour malts, apples and berries. Flavor is very sour malts with some notes of apples. Great stuff.

(Note: Im not quite sure I am reviewing the right beer. My bottle is labeled "Panil Baririquee" but has the label of the bottle shown in the "Barriquee Reserve" post... )
The beer pours a gorgeous, muddled pink, almost like a fruited Berliner Weisse. It sits in the glass a regal, dark purple color with maroon and ruby hues. The beer pours with a head of miniscule, creamy white bubbles that form a pillow, and then quickly settles into a fat scrim around the beer. In body, the beer is dark and hazy, but clear of particles and cloudiness. On the nose, the beer smells of light vinegar, cherries, leather, and nearly vinous. Touches of grape and soft plum dance on the edges of the scent along with rich vanilla from the oak. The funky leather and cherry scents are earthy and rich with vinegar, which I adore, but they are also constrained and mellow. The nose of this beer revels in subtle complexity; it is funky, but not in a way that would kick your nose. On the tongue, the beer tastes tart with acidity, sweet with fruity malt, and bitter with oak tannin. The oak leaves a strange twinge to the pucker in your cheeks. The beer finishes dry and tannic. In flavor, the beer begins as sweet plum juice, tinged with tart cherry leather, this bulls head on into a wall of rich, oak tannin that blankets the middle of the sip, all but obliterating the fruity notes and bringing vanilla, earth and finally a touch of chocolate into play. Touches of grape juice and rich red wine can also be sensed in the start of the sip, while the finish is long and decadent with oak, vanilla, touches of tart grapes, and bitter herbal tannin. The aftertaste is hard to distinguish from the finish, as the beer has tremendous lasting power in the mouth. For all intents and purposes, the finish and the aftertaste are the same. In body, the beer is on the light side of medium, with a middling carbonation that gives a nice pillow to the tongue. Mouthfeel is smooth, if a bit watery, providing superb drinkability until the beer hits the back of the palate. In the back, the tannin does touch with a quick bite of astringency, but this quickly fades to just leave a bit of tightness in the tongue. The mouth is left slightly dry, with just a touch of saliva oozing in to cancel the lingering acidity of the beer. Overall, this is yet another superb Flanders Red. This particular beer revels in the rich character it gained from unique Bordeaux cognac barrels. Admittedly, I have not drank a lot of cognac from Bordeaux (I thought Cognac could only be made in a region surrounding the town of Cognac?) but I think an experienced Cognac drinker would definitely find subtle hints within this beer reminiscent of that drink. This is a Flanders Red of subtle intrigue and beauty, like a fine red wine. It unfurled on my tongue like a puzzle, and I very much enjoyed that. My chief complaint with the beer comes from its thinness. I want my Flanders Reds to be medium bodied, and this one is just a little too far below this bench mark for me. It is superbly drinkable, but loses a little oomf. The beers tannic structure also allows it to grip the mouth quite nicely, and provides some amazing complexities, though it is a little too raw for my personal tastes. In the end though, its a great Flanders red.

bottiglia del 2012. non so se fatta da losi o dal nuovo birraio. Comq ottimi gli aromi ciliegia e tamarindo. un aroma di legnoo e dicantina che lo rendono particolarmente vinosa. Il sapore è quello del vino senza solfiti (vinbo del contadino) tornano le ciliege sottospirito. Ottima ed elegantissiama. Fantastica per gli aperitivi e i brindisi
Batch 16 2012. Pours a dark amber with small off white head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is oak and dark fruits. Medium mouthfeel with plum, figs, oak, and light tart finish. Good.

750ml bottle (shared by FatPhil, thanks). Hazy copper color. No head. Almonds, peanuts, earthy, sour, woody, yarrow in aroma. Herbal, yarrow, mint, earthy sour taste. At some point I get dark chocolate as well (just for a millisecond or three). Although I cant taste alcohol sense of strength is there. Nice one.

750ml bottle (Alvinne Webshop)
Slightly vegetal, artichokey, dusty and nutty - chestnutty, hint of mint spearmint, but dust too dominant. Gentle carbonation, a bit watery. Yup, chalky mint. Simple red ale body, very little sourness. Very disappointing. More herbal and again minty later. Does cover the 8% well, but thats about as positive as I can be.

Bottled labeled 2007. Been holding on to this one for a while, and started to get worried it might be deteriorating. Nothing to worried about. Delicious. A little bit, spicy, peppery, funky horse blanket type wild flavors, tastefully balanced.

Bottle (750ml): Hazy, brown and no head. Malty, old oak, sour, lactic, sour red fruit, rhubarb and hints of citrus. Dry, moderate to highly sour and low bitterness. Unripe fruit and citrus. Clean, lactic. Not bretty. Layers, food friendly. 
Very interesting. Amazing cleanliness for an extremely sour beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Birra commovente, a cui davvero non manca nulla. Gusto molto ricco e complesso, che evoca spiriti caramellati e fruttati insieme, il tutto legato da una forte presenza vinosa e decisamente acida che ammalia il palato, persistente e penetrante. Corpo setoso che scivola già senza che ci si accorga degli otto gradicelli anonimi. S-p-e-t-t-a-c-o-l-a-r-e.

Yowza! Okay, we have a strong oak barreled nose, reminiscent of an American bourbon. Then we have ripe, fruity tartness...enticingly sour, followed by a dry, lingering bitterness that is subtle but also tannic and quite wine-like. Old beer envelopes the mouth and nose. The mouthfeel is tremendous, like a slick or velvet or oily characteristic. Full and lush and yummy mouthfeel. This is an incredibly delicious and complex brew. I loved every sip and felt like I had gone on a wonderful journey with this 750ml bottle, as I watched Wolverine on Blu-ray. An outstanding beverage and I cant wait to slowly consume this stuff again!!

Flaska från De Molens webshop drucken med ölföreningen julöl 2013. En relativt torr, stram och syrlig relativt klassisk flamländsk rödöl. Men inte svårdrucken och syran är ganska snäll och balanseras av en lätt sötma. Lätt kropp och fina bäriga smaker. Körsbär, syrliga plommon, lingon och trä. Riktigt god.

Copper, slight haze, beige head. Aroma of dark fruit, tart cherries, toasty malt, very light hint of plastic. Flavor of toasty malt, tart cherries, some nutty notes, light puckery acidity.

Aroma decisamente acetico, ma anche molto cantinoso. In bocca è elegante, sapida e acidula, ma riesce a soddisfare il palato in modo molto equilibrato nonostante la complessità della birra. Giù il cappello...

(750 ml - brassin à 9%) - Bière brunâtre, voilée, aux reflets rubis-bourgognes. La mousse est mince. Au nez, cest fruité, boisé, sauvage... et ça se confirme en bouche pour faire palpiter les papilles. Lacidité est saisissante, ce qui donne une certaine sensation de viscosité sur la langue. Des pointes de petits fruits rouges viennent se mêler à merveille à cette concoction plutôt bien foutue. Le boisé rapplique en finale, mais plus en sensation quen saveurs. Plaisir acétique, quand tu nous tiens!

Shared bottle at craft ale house. Pours hazy reddish brown with minimal head. The aroma is tart cherry and vinegar. The taste has a nice tartness cherry, light sweetness, dry finish.

On the nose I get a nice subtle ripe and sweet fruits with a light vicious vinegar hint in the background. Mhm.. Really enjoying this aroma. Its actually most sweet, while I was expecting it to be vinegar acidic. Not extreme but definitely nice! The taste has lovely tones of vinous red wine, lots of wood and tannins, old dedicated leafs, red berries and brown sugar. Lots of flavor, yet its a bit watery. Soft oily on the mouthfeel with a gentle prickling carbonation level. Not even a hint of the alcohol here, but it has hints of Christmas. Pine needles and something almost spicy. This is something I could drink quite a lot of. 24.07.2013

Light body, dry. Very easy to drink. This is batch 12 bought at Rincon Valley, Santa Rosa, Ca. A very nice, refreshing sour. It is a bit thin but I dont think it takes away from the flavor or drinkability.
Pours a yellowish brown slightly hazy. Tart cherries and dark fruit. Finish is light and clean with old carbonation. Very nice beer.

[bottle]
Sweet and slightly vinegary aroma; pickle juicy lambic. Hazy chestnut appearance under an off white, thin cover. Sour and dry flavour with some paper and goatiness. The dryness is unpleasant as though an infection. Metallic. Light body, high carbonation, sour and goaty finish. [Perhaps not stored properly or too old?]

It rather tart on the palate, not as tart as expected though, with a pleasant carbonation level. Medium to full body. The flavor has a faint nutty, caramel touch, with lemon, a faint touch of vinegar and some funky notes. Long finish with lemon, caramel and nuts. Sort of disappoints this one, was expecting more sourness, at least judging from what I remember the European version to be. But its definitely not a bad beer anyway. 130815

Bottle. Pours murky amber with an off white head. Aroma of red berries, sour apples, malt and caramel. Flavor is sweet and sour with some cherries, lemon, caramel and some funk. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle 750ml @ Hotel Room, Hampton Inn, San Marcos, CA

dark red appearance with HUGE head. aroma is very light. some brett, apples, oak, fruit. low sour, soft mouthfeel with medium carbonation. small sour finish with some apples, oak and tartness. Overall: Very boring compared to other flemish reds.

750 ml bottle, 2012 vintage, Batch #15, Bottle #1184. Served in a Unibroue tulip, the beer pours a reddish/brown color with about an inch off-white head. Head retention and lacing are both good. Aroma is nice, the brew smells like tart cherries, oak, green apples, funk and vinegar. Taste is similar to the aroma, it tastes like tart cherries, grape juice, dark fruit, oak, green apples and vinegar. Even though its mostly tart, theres some fruity sweetness noticeable. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its coating and is well carbonated. I think this is a good, tart, enjoyable brew. Definitely worth a try, Ill have to get another bottle to age and see how it turns out. $16.99 a bottle.

Bottle to glass. Pours an almost clear deep copper to light brown color with a thin off-white head. Aroma is quite sour, with notes of sour grapes and cherries. Flavor is a sour vinegar, with light hints of fruity sour/sweetness. Light to medium in body with a lasting astringent sour punch on the back of the tongue. Oily in texture. Delightful.

Hazy, yellowish brown with yellow-tan head. A little muddy looking. Aroma is light decaying wood, tart and dry cherries, light wine grape, vegetable. At first, I noted muted sour garbage. I think this may have been a bit harsh; it gets a bit better in the aroma once it has time to breath. Body is light-medium and watery. Flavor is cedar, tart, old vegetable, overcooked broccoli in old, drying mud. These negative notes come out when drinking with the mouth open, allowing air to waft over the tongue and up to the nose, leading me to believe they are actually properties of the aroma. Also, pleasurable and nicely rounded yet sharp fruity sourness overshadows these flaws, however, that old veg/garbage note nags at me, just as a looming deadline might while Im trying to enjoy my vacation. This is a very conflicted beer for me, and I wander if it was stored properly on its journey to my mouth.

Really a great beer. Nice, controlled funk aroma with south plum, cherry and dried apricot. A nice touch of something like bretta. Pours red with a big pillowy head of foam and great lacing on the side of plastic im drinking Iron in the park. Finish is light sour and tangy with some bitterness. Soft carbonation, slick feel. Bottle.

2010 Bottle to pint glass
Aroma of lemon, funk, and vinegar. Sludgy orange brown with a long lasting bubbly white head. Nice strong flemish sour taste of tart cherry and apple with some malt vinegar. Nicely balanced and smooth.

Ah, the glory of a lactic-forward Flemish sour. Nice black cherry sourness, heaps of oak without overboard tannins, still some acetic character. Deftly avoids the common Flemish sour pitfall of tasting like rotten cola. Dry woody finish.

Sourness is pronounced but nothing near as intense as is achieved by some sours, notably Cantillon. This may limit interest for the hardcore but makes for accessibility. Complexity and balance provide character. The aroma is lively with notes of vinegar and some funkiness akin to shiitake mushrooms. The barrel contribution is somewhat restrained and in balance.

[5097-20130202] Bottle. Mild cheesy grains yeast aroma. Hazy, red brown body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Cheesy grain malt flavour has a sour malt base and long aftertaste. Medium body. Good. (7/3/7/4/15) 3.6
(@ Sourfest 2013, Buffalo, NY)

750 ml bottle into tulip glass; Bottle #1048, Batch #9, 2007 vintage. Pours lightly hazy deep ruby red color with a 1-2 finger dense cream colored head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with some moderate streaming carbonation. Aromas of sour cherry, green apple, red grape, pepper, clove, floral, oak, hay, red wine vinegar, funk, light leather, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/funky yeast notes with moderate oak barrel presence. Taste of tart cherry, green apple, red grape, floral, clove, oak, hay, red wine vinegar, funk, light leather, and yeast earthiness. Fair amount of fruity and earthy tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of tart cherry, green apple, red grape, clove, oak, floral, hay, red wine vinegar, funk, light leather, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice balance and complexity of fruity, tart, and earthy yeast ester flavors; with moderate malt, oak, and acidity; and a great sweetness/acidity balance with zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a fairly slick and moderately acidic mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice Flanders red ale. All around nice balance and complexity of fruity, tart, and earthy yeast flavors with moderate malt and oak balance; and very smooth to sip on for 8% with the moderate acidity. A very enjoyable offering.

2010. Ambré rousse
Sauvage. Brett caramel. Boisé champignon. Corsé. Belle effervescence. Fraiche. Levure sauvage. Bonbon. Sour. Un petit délice.

Aroma is fairly malty with some nice caramel, toasted bread, light chocolate and nuttiness. light complimentary oak character. The acidity is nice and light with some cherry and berry notes. 
Pours a fairly clear amber brown color with a moderately thick light tan head. The head recedes steadily but a thin film remains on top and along the edges. Moderate lacing and small legs. 
Flavor starts with some light maltiness with some caramel and light nuttiness and toasted bread. Moderate acidity brings in a nice cherry and berry flavor. Mid palate you get a medium low oak note. Medium low bitterness. Acidity dries out the finish, but its still fairly sweet. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall a nice beer, but its lacking some of the complexity I expect from a nice Flemish Red or Oud Bruin. A good beginner sour.

750ml bottle during poker Friday night. Decided to do a European night which was nice. Pours reddish brown with thin soapy head. tastes of dark cherries, vinegar, tannic, grape skins, oak, and licorice. A touch thin but very tasty.
My first sour and exactly what I expected..decent aroma, golden opaque appearance, tastes not too tart, overall a good first sour experience.

Murky unfiltered ruby brown with wee bubble trim head. Dip Dab sherbert juicy nose. Really smooth well disguised oxidation before a big upturn unleashing a fresh sour waterfall with touches of cherry. The cognac softness the tartness into a very very quenching finish. So smooth. If you stuck a straw in the bottle and let a non-beer/sour fiend have a sook youd probably get interesting but very favourable reactions. Balanced at every turn. Bottle, Deeblo Doesnt Rate Tasting, from Beer Hive, Edinburgh

Bottle shared with Lupuloadicto. Rubi colour with a good lasting head, off-white colour. Flavor is acidic, wood and slightly apple. Flavor is mild sourish, wooden notes are present. Maybe infected; I must try again.

Red amber colour, white head. Aroma of red wine, red fruits, funk, caramel and redcurrant. Light sweet flavour, light funk, malts, red fruits and some acetic acid. Quite thin body, dry, red wine finish.
(From 75cL bottle @ ZZT VII, Oirschot 2013. Thanks for sharing, ceasar!)
Bottle @ ZZT VII, thx to everyone for sharing their bottles. Typical flemish sour aroma, but not really complex enough. Bit thin on the flavor. Maybe on the fresh side.
Bottle shared by Caesar, hazy reddish color, virtually no head. Smell and taste sourish, unripe fruits. For me its a bit I too I sour, but its a nice beer.
Bottle @ZZT7 thx to caesar. Ruby colour with a minimal white head. Smells rusty, blood, sour, cherry. Tastes quite sour, cherry, red fruits, fresh. Medium to full body, soft carbo.

Tasted at ZZT 7 thanks to Caesar.  Pours hazy amber with a small tan head.  Aroma of barnyard, tart red fruits, cherries, light wood.  Flavor is light sweet, moderate sour and acidic.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

750ml bottle, 2012, Batch #15, Bottle #813.  Pours almost opaque reddish brown with a thick, foamy, off-white head.  Aroma is tart, bright, woody cherries with noticeable funkiness. Taste is tart cherry skins, oak, wood and tannins and is earthy, citric, vinous and funky.  Bright and tart on the palate, fairly sour, really nice carbonation. Great finish.  Perfectly balanced; every aspect of this beer is standout. Just terrific.

bottle at home ...bath 16 2012 bottle 1170...  copper ... thin white head ... soft mellow fruits ... light hard boiled sweetie nose ... soft fruits ... mellow soft ... ligth sour ... .. no tart bite ... quite fruits... little creamy ...

Bottle, thanks Niall. Cloudy amber red with off white head. Musty funky aroma, little vingar and some fruitiness. Taste of berries, funk, very little vinegar, wood. Minimal sourness. Easy going and nice
Bottle at Craig?s house. Don?t liked the smell much but really like the taste. Strange reddish colour.

Bottle @ HTX Tasting. Pours hazy brown with a offwhite head. Aroma is light sour with grapes, brett, wood, light vinegar. Flavor is sourness, grapes, wet wood, oak, grapes, dusty, barnyard, little vinegar. Thin to medium body, lively carbonation. Nice one. 210513

Bottle. Clear brown/amber with medium foamy off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, brett, sour and a little vinegar. Flavour is malt, fruit, sour, caramel, little vinegar, little acid, little barnyard, little tart and a little over carbonated.

Bottle @ HenrikSoegaard tasting. Clear amber with a  big and lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dark fruit and wood. Flavor is quite sweet and light acidic. Dry and light acidic finish. 210513
Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Amber colour. Heavy wonderfull sour aroma. Average sour nice flavor. Long moderate bitter ok finish. Oily palate.
Bottle @ Gallafest tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are lactose acid, fruits, berries, little caramel, malt and hops. Vinous and mild.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2015 Batch #16, 2012, Bottle #2161. Pours dark purple-brownish red from the bottle. Small bit of cream colored head. aroma of sour cherries, blackberries. Big heavy mouthfeel with very little carbonation. Lots of fruit up front with a good tart punch and dry oak finish. Cheery, blackberries, and grapes. Not sure I like the big body on this and tend to enjoy more effervescent sours. Not bad, but I could do without it as well.

Bottle @ home from Hallinghansen... Thanks my friend...vintage ´09.. It pours cloudy red brown with a medium head.. the aroma is sour, spicy, fruity and wood... The flavor is fresh, sour, citrus, dusty, woody and fruits! very nice! liked it a lot! ...
25 ounce bottle from Hot City Pizza from Beer Week; nice sour note. Frothy head.

Awesome. Pours a brownish rust color with a reddish hue and an off-white head. Aroma is sour, apple, oak, and "aged" funk. Taste is sour, apple, raisin, rum, and other beer aroma similar to the ones found in the "brett" varieties. Palate: plenty of carbonation adds to the complexity and bitterness. Finishes dry and aromatic, nice!

Pours a hazy reddish-brown nice head and little lacing. Fruity aroma of sour cherries with pleasant sourness, a tiny bit of oak. Taste is fruity, cherries, abit of berries, some lacto, little caramel sweetness (really just a bit), oak, vinious presence. Medium-low mouthfeel with good carbonation. Very surprised by this one. I might buy a few more next time i go to ontario.

Bottle from the LCBO. Just getting into sour beers and I quite enjoyed this one. Lots of vinegar upfront--initially I thought too much vinegar for my tastes, but it smoothed out. Enjoyed the bitterness, the sourness, and the array of fruits underneath the initial bite. A complex beer, for sure, but at 14$ I might only grab it once more (at least for this year)!

750 mL bottle. Pours a dark mahogany with a thin white head. Aromas is sour and woody; yeast, sour cherry, vanilla, earth and clove.  Palate is smooth and gently carbonated. Very complex. Different and tasty.

This was my first experience with a sour and I was pleasantly surprised, Im not very good at describing what I taste, to me its really personal preference. I really enjoyed this beer.  The aroma was a bit interesting, smelled like an empty jar of pickles.  While some may not consider this good, I love pickles :) Id drink it again!

Sour, basement aromas come through strong (as soon as the bottle is opened), with a slightly honey-sweetness coming through as well. Very dark brown, hazy and long lasting thick head. Sour comes through on first sip, followed by sweetness that slowly develops into maltyness on the tongue. Not cloying at all. Complex and delicious. Caramel comes through as it warms some more. Thick mouthfeel and quite heavily carbonated. Great.
Bottle at James place. Pours amber with a beige head. Tart and fruity, some light berry-like sweetness, medium sour/lacto notes. Quite drinkable.

Couleur ambre rougeoyant avec léger col de mousse coriace. Les tons de cuivre patiné dominent lorsque penchée. Elle sent littéralement la rose ; on ajoute un peu de caramel et du bois pour la vue densemble. Peut-être une pointe de chocolat en finale. Très amère et salivante. Étonnante attaque de pommes et de vin blanc. Aqueuse et brève ; lalcool est fort bien contrôlé. Rappelle un cidre acidulé au maximum. Pommes, agrumes. Elle possède beaucoup de sucre fruitier aussi. Un genre qui ne laisse personne indifférent, et je pourrais comprendre certains de ne pas aimer.

Tasted from the bottle, on 08/02/2013.
Pours copper/light brown, perfectly clear, with just a tiny off-white head.
Aroma is quite intense, tartness dominates, accompanied with sour berries, raspberries as well, a hint of grapes skin in the end.
Taste is also tart upfront, but not acetic, then come wild funky notes, mixed with dry wine and grape juice. After warming up raspberries show up, as well as a bit of oaky vanilla character.
Mouthfeel is medium bodied, medium-light carbonated.
Aftertaste is of funk&sourness, with a faint warming alcohol sensation at the back.
Overall, a well balanced, not too sour indeed, pretty drinkable and rather tasty beer.
Recommended+

this is my first post...panil sour is a great way to start and it might be all downhill from here (haha)...straight from the bottle will be all my posts

Pinkish amber, orange zest, slight funk. Wine like flavor, fruit forward, slight sourness. Nice
VEry solid beer. Sour, but not super, tart, refreshing, not exactly following nay traditional guidelines making it unique.

750mL bottle, pours a hazy dark amber with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt vinegar, some soured fruits, and some red berries. Flavour of moderately soured dark fruits, quite a high vinegary quality, some red berries, and wood. Too vinegary for me, but quite complex and not too sour. Overrated, but decent stuff.

Taster at DBS. Aroma of light cherry; flavor is odd and funky cherry, not great. Palate and taste are average at best. Fair sour beer.

Bottled a year ago.  Notes of wood, leather, lacto, and mild sour cherry with a hint of cognac and caramel.  Moderate sourness 5/10.  Slightly disappointing, but certainly a good Flanders ale.

From the 100 Belgian Beers To Try Before You Die book. Had an old and a new bottle side by side. Both poured an amber brown colour with a thin beige head. The older bottle had an aroma of raisins, blue cheese, balsamic vinegar, oak and alcohol. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and a oily mouth-feel. The newer bottle had more balsamic vinegar on the nose with oak, lemon and alcohol notes again. The newer version was more tart, however, I preferred the older version. 3 / 3 split around the table though. Great!
Annata 2009 in pompa. Quando si dice tanta roba. Questa barrique è qualcosa di veramente unico. Molto avvolgente in bocca riesce a coprire bene i gradi alcolici.
Pretty good. Not my favorite Flanders red but pretty good. Slightly overpriced though.

Pours amber red with a decent off-white head.  Aroma is vinegar, funk, oak.  Taste is nice and sour with the oak coming through nicely balanced in the finish.  Palate is excellent with perfect carbonation and medium body.  Very nice sour.

Batch 15.  Dark red-brown body.  Large fluffy off-white head.  Sticky lacing.  Nose is musty oak, lemon, light cherries, invigorating.  Flavor is a bit richer, with a bolder vinous character complementing the citric acidity, cherries, oak, and light must.  Medium to light bodied, smooth carbonation, nice refreshing acidity in the finish, lightly sour.  Pairs wonderfully with prosciutto.
Great barrel scent on the scent, with some lemon funk. Great mix of sour and wood almost like a wine, great sour.

Picked up two bottles at Hunger Mountain. Enjoyed at cellar temp in an HFS glass. Bottle 931 of batch #15.

A - Plum red beer with a 3 finger pillowy head that fades fast. 

S - Hints of vinegar, cherries and oak on the nose. 

T - Very mild up front taste, hint of metallic and tart characters at the middle. Finish is cherries, sweet citrus and bitter yet tart sour candies. 

M - Light body

O - This is pretty good. Paid $14 for a 750. I consider this a good deal.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2017 Bottle back in 2012 Batch #15 Bottle #868. Poured a dark caramel red. Foamy top. Strong sour. Medium dark malt flavors. Much more dry, than sweet. Oak barrel notes mellow out the malt end. But the big complex sour notes definitely dominate this wonderful brew. UPDATE: Draft at Bru Craft in April 2017. Sweeter and thinner than I remember.  Darker pour too. Liquorice cocoa raisins. Root beer. Red wine. Blackberries. Keeping my 2012 rating.

Pours a rich deep copper reddish color with a lively three finger eggshell foam... Aromas are complex and pleasant... touches of tart dark fruit; plum, black cherry and blackberry mingle with toasty oak notes of vanilla,  earthy wood and a touch of funky brett peak through. On the palate its a lot of the same with great balance between the tart fruity sweetness and the deep woody barrel notes. Great medium mouthfeel with a nice rustic finish.

Bottled in 2005, carbon copy of the beers picture on this site. Served in Founders snifter.

A: Pours a hazy brown with a nice off-white head. Sticks around for a little while.

S: Tart smelling with a definite must. Some grape skins and some oakiness.

T: Woody and a little pucker from the sour. Some tartness too. Some fruit skins and unripe berries are present as well. Has a slight wine taste with a little acetone/nail polish finish.

M: Dry finish, some fruity berries left on the palate and a nice prickly carbonation.

O: I can appreciate the style, but flanders red ales are definitely not my favorite.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-30-2011

Bouteille de 750ml achetée en Ontario par mon ami Patrick. La bière est brune et ne mousse pas. Le nez est très boisé, sous ce bois il y a des cerises et du malt sucré. En bouche le liquide se présente sous un angle boisé. Il y a des fruits fermentés, des cerises. Elle est moyenne mince, le suret nest pas désagréable ni il est trop présent.
Bottle 750ml. Pours clear dark brown with low white head. Good lacing. Aroma is wildy, malt, caramel. Taste is of sourness, malt, caramel. Nice balance.

14/04/2012 - Bottle 750 ml. Appearance: Pour amber with a small with a thin off-white/orange head. Aroma: Horse blanket, caramel, sourness. Taste: Acidic, sour, horse blanket and caramel. Wood? A good one.

750ml bottle - 2009 vintage bottle #239.
Muddy amber brew with a bit of off-white head.  Nose is sour with lots of barrel aging - flavor of stone fruits and grain.

Un flacon de 75 cl acheté quelque part à Toronto.  Une belle robe brune acajou et son anneau de mousse.  Un nez qui se divise en deux grands axes à travers une base maltée chocolatée : dune part la présence de fruits gorgés par un bénéfique séjour dans la barrique et dune autre, une aigreur qui se présente comme les plus fines notes dun balsamique de grande qualité.  Au goût, des raisins, des pommes et des cerises bonifiés par la magie de lenfûtage et de toutes les petites bibittes qui sy développent.  Des notes surettes et une capacité de développer des notes de vin aigre qui sont toujours dociles et agréables.  Des malts qui interviennent au bon moment avec leur douceur complexifiée.  Une bouche totalement maîtrisée avec son corps de moyenne densité et son pétillement qui chamboule le palais.  Une finale très forte en fruits et en microbes sucrés.  Très facile à boire.  Je dirais même plus, un vrai régal.

Appearance:  medium clear reddish brown, with a short, tan head and little lacing or legs.   Aroma: apple cider vinegar, with notes of raspberry and raisin, some white wine (?) or sour milk.   Taste: tart cherry, a sour lactic tang, and sweet caramel malts, with a healthy dose of funk.   Finish:  finishes woody, dry, and a little pucker-y.   Notes: 	Only my second or third sour, and had it only a couple days after the Rodenbach Grand Cru, which was clearly superior.  This seemed rough around the edges by comparison.   Batch #11 from 2009, bottle 132.  From the Rare Beer Club.

750 ml bottle.  Poured a brownish/red with a miniscule white head. Aroma is sour fruit and band-aid (borrowed the term from another rating as it made sense).   Taste is sour berries and malt vinegar. Nice tangy bite up front followed by a moderately sour/bitter finish.  Unlike any sour Ive tried before.

750ml. bottle.The color is a clear ruby with a thin beige head.The aroma is of alcohol and malt and also fruits. The taste is very strong for an 8% with malt    sour fruits  some hops. It leaves a sour taste in your mouth.

750ml bottle from Josh and shared with some friends in Hamilton, think from a 2008 private order. Vibrant mahogany with a slightly off-white head. Musty, sour,  reminiscent of earthmonk (with a couple of years on it) with some raisins, molasses, and a lot of malt. Mild carbonation, moderate to full body, earthy, more funk on the palate then I would have expected based on the aroma - much better with a couple of years on it.

Bottle shared at MuckFest 3 - Friday evening addition. Pours a rich deep copper hue, gentle haze, with frothy tannish head atop. Mellow tannish head dies to a small ring, laces small. Aromas are rich red berry, cherries and raspberries, tart lactic element, touches of vinegar. Really rich, touch of sweet malt, a bit of vinegar. Rich berry nose. Initial is thinner on the palate, a firm sourness, red berries. Some firm sourness, tart berry, cherries and raspberries. A touch of lactic, red wine, and tart yogurt. Finish lingers tart, a touch toasty. Pretty nice.

From a 75cl bottle slightly hazy amber with a white head. Aroma of barnyard, malt, fruits, hops and a hint alcohol. Possibly medium sweet with a very nice sourness and a hint of bitterness in the finish. Very refreshing. Delicious sour!

750 ml bottle from Wine and Cheese Place. 2009 vintage, batch #11. Bottle 2499. Pours a clear, dark amber color with a small off-white head that settles quickly. Aroma of oak, dark fruits, earthy funk, balsamic, leaves, and vegetal notes. Even more vegetal notes in the flavor, but not overpowering, with a ton of oak, plus dark fruits, tart berries, and balsamic. Light-medium bodied, with a tart, vegetal mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Not bad, but a weird sour.

Batch 11 - bottle 1030. Shared by WorldWideStout at a recent tasting.

A: Light brown, little head, very little lacing.

S: Unusual scents make me a bit cautious and unsure. The funky bandaid monster has visited this beer.

T: Spicy flavors and weirdness. Im also getting wood (in the taste), funky sourness, basement mustiness, and bandaids.

M: Ok feel, but again, this tasted out of kilter.

D: Im always thankful to try a beer I havent had, but now I know I dont need to purchase this one or seek it out.

Bottle. Pours a brick red/brown with light hazy sediment adding translucency toward the end of the pour. The head never really amounts to much, and is gone completely within a few minutes. Aroma is interesting-- immediately after it hits the glass my first thoughts were of cold, fresh seaweed. Odd, I know, but unmistakeable to me. Then after breathing, the expected sour cherry/berry came forward big time, along with light wood, light yoghurt, and light rice vinegar. The palate is light and lively, with flavours of tart unripe fieldberries, subtle caramel, unsweetened ("natural") yoghurt, with light woody astringency and moderate sourness in the finish. Not puckeringly sour, but highly refreshing and beautifully balanced.

text: Bottle to oversized snifter (2008 vintage).  Looks decent; dark with very low carbonation and bubbly lacing.  Smells good; tart.  Tastes overpriced with an overpriced mouthfeel.  Overpriced.

75cl bottle. Pours a dark reddish color with a medium beige head. Aroma is funky and acidic, mostly of sour cherries. Very similar to Italian aceto balsamico. The flavor has an underlying malty sweetness topped with the sour cherries and hints of spices. The finish is tart. Good carbonation.
Fantastic and well rounded, sour beer. Great pallet feel and a delicious companion on a warm day.

750mL bottle from the LCBO. Pours a deep brown with a bit of white head that dissipates pretty quickly. Smell is quite sour, with some cherry and oak barrel. Body is good, but carbonation is a bit weak. Taste is overbearingly sour a tiny bit of sweetness in the aftertaste, but its kind of like drinking sour patch kids.

Excited for this one. 2011 batch #14. Poured into my Ommegang tulip-esque glass with a mahogany clear pour. The nose I just what I was expecting - old wood, funk, and a touch of basalmic vinegar. The flavor is initially sour, followed a bit of undesirable graininess. The finish is smooth and woody. Nice beer.
birra equilibrata dove predomina il vino rosso e le note legnose con una punta di dolcezza (vaniglia?) che ci lascia una splendido retrogusto in bocca. Bilanciata e non banale. P.s. wiiiiild ....

Batch #12.  2010.  Bottle #1057.  Served in a wine glass.  Pours a fairly-clear reddish-mahogany color with a good white head that fades relatively quickly before falling to a thin cap.  The nose brings a nice acidity and underlying red fruits plus a bit of oak and lactic acidity.  Flavor pushes those components a bit further, but also has an underlying tannic graininess that detracts a bit, especially from the mouthfeel.  Not a bad beer by any means, though I preferred the nose to the flavor/palate.
Pours a hazy brown with huge white head.  Aroma is sour just like the flavor. A nice bit of malt balance though with the flavor.

750ml bottle. Pours a cloudy orange-brown body with a very small white head, almost no retention.
Aroma is sour cherry, yeast, old wood barel, old dried hops, fungus, even so, its fresh and crispy.
Taste is tart, wine like, sour cherry, same old hops, some herbal nunaces, apple vinegar.
Very nice.

Bottle, 06 vintage shared at 4:20.  Muddy brown pour.  Red wine and oak aromas.  A little sweet, but not overly so.  Red wind, caramel malt, oak, and maybe a hint of vanilla.  Good mouthfeel and balance.  A very nice wild ale...

(shared 1yr-old 750mL bottle from LCBO) Pours a cloudy reddish tea with a thin off-white thin head. Aroma tangy sour apple, a little cherry, leathery wood, a bit of vinegar and funk. Flavour is fairly sour and a little vinegar, with tart cherry and apple cider, oak, earthy barnyard funk, acetic acid, malts in the finish. Mouthfeel is quite full and oily but still with some champagne effervescence. Complex, surprisingly quenching and good with food.

Serving: 750 ml bottle from Fire Works Leesburg.  It pours a slightly cloudy, deep tea like color with a frothy off white head.  The nose has a tangy sour apple note.  The flavor is slightly earthy with a slight metallic note, apple cider, a little vegetal wood, and a touch of lacto.  A little "meatier" than other sours Ive had.  I think the cognac barrel adds a nice dimension to this.  Different but good.

750ml bottle 
8.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on March 23, 2012 after purchasing from the Queens Quay LCBO outlket in Toronto, Ontario.  The beer pours a deep, semi-translucent copper colour with a very thin white head.  Aroma is earthy funk, and tart cherries.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with mil;d carbonation.  Flavour is sour funk, wood, and tart fruit.  There is a definite vinegar tome to this sour.

Batch 14/bottle 821: Sour cherry aroma, with ketchup hints. Hazy ochre, thin head. Sour cherry flavor, abundant notes of oak and twigs.Malt and grain finish. Not overly sour, but the lactic character is evident in the finish. A good introduction to Flemish Reds for the newcomer.

It pours murky chestnut with red and golden yellow highlights; the head is mousse-like and off-white. The aroma has notes of: fermenting apple cores, barnyard funk, sour cherries, slight leather, and apricots. The taste is high sour and medium acid, it finishes with a malty drier note; there are notes of: sour cherries, dry cider, slight raspberry, straw, and a malty aftertaste. The palate is medium-light bodied with a long sour finish; light carbonation; sticky. Overall, its a little unbalanced but very appetizing.

Bottle. Cloudy amber/brown. Aroma is Shiraz wine. Earthy, wood, dark berries, port wine, prunes. Oily in the mouth. Everything from the aroma follows in the flavour. Almost cranberry juice/shiraz tannic quality. Bready and sour but not overwhelming. No unnecessary sweetness added for the faint of heart. I opened this December 2011 bottle as soon as I bought it, and its delightfully balanced. If THIS is sour ale, Im a convert.
Magnifique teinte de coucher de soleil avec une effervescence active mais raisonnable. Bel équilibre entre le malt et lacidité. Ne fait rien dextraordinaire mais demeure lexpérience attendu.
A great sour ale. It drinks like a good champagne with up-front cidery tartness. It is incredibly drinkable and refreshing, which is a problem given its relative cost and alcohol content.

13/01/2012 Open Baladin (tap). Color mogano profondo, dai riflessi rubino. Al naso si apre con un potentissimo e impressionante bouquet di aromi. Si presenta vinosa, leggermente acetica, con netti sentori legnosi, di vaniglia, muffa, cantina, ma anche note di frutta, ciliegia, banana, cacao. In bocca ha un bel carattere, le note dolci di ciliegia, cacao, caramello si sposano in un mirabile equilibrio con le noti acide e acetiche conferite dalla botte, importanti ma mai invadenti, che le donano una impronta grezza, terrosa, sanguigna, e una lieve tannicità sul finale. Corpo snello, carbonazione soft. Una gran birra.
Bottle from Jeff for Christmas. Pours a reddish tea color with a nice white head. Aroma and tasteof sourness/tart red grapes.  This is awesome. I really like sour ales.

Last creation of Renzo, lover of wood from time immemorial, is an absolute novelty in Italy. These dark beer is aged in French oak barrels.The barrique hosts three fermentations, 15 days in iron vessel, 90 days in barriques coming from cognac and bordeaux and 30 days in bottle. The result is a beer who marries a strong alcohol strenght, 8% with an extraordinary drinkability and a incomparable bouquet of aromas.

Sampled at the DC Local Tasting a 2006 750ml bottle pours a translucent copper amber with some spitty white head.  Nose is lightly sour, some vinegar, light wood.  Flavor is sweet, vinegar, perfume, brown malts.  Medium bodied, cherry finish.  A little thin.  I think I like these bottles fresh.
Bottle (2006). Pours reddish copper with faint head. Aroma is sour dark fruit, caramel, and roasted malt. Flavor is sour fruit, caramel, and bread malt. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

Bottle.  Red, brown colour in a snifter.  Thin white head.  Lots of oak in the aroma with brett and white wine grapes.  Medium bodied and quite bubbly.  Flavour is initially fairly sweet leading to sour cherry and Macintosh apple with more brett, mild woodiness, yeast and plenty of sourness.  Long and sour finish.

Absolutely loved this beer.  From a 750ml bottles, pours a dark ruby red/black. A soft head which melt to persistent lacings, sweet and sour hit the nose, acidic, yeasty, barrel.  Starts very strong and full on the palate and finishes incredibly smooth and clean.  Outstanding brew.
Red colour and decent carbonation. Sour apple aroma. Sour and slightly bitter flavour. Sour fruit. Quite yum.

shared vintage 2009 750ml. pours a deep red with a small off white head which fades to nothing.  lactic acid nose with some barnyard funk, wood, earth, oak, odd vegetable and dark fruits.  med body, tart throughout with lactic acid, lots of oak, barnyard funk, light vinegar, cherries and lemon.  sour dry finish with more oak and light funk.
Pours red. Nise is Malta sweet fruity and sour acidic qualities, musty wines m. Flavor is clean no. funky sour and some earthy malt qualities. Lacic acid and little other funkiness. really nice.

2009, Batch #11.  Amber, lots of malt and barrel flavor.  Thank goodness it isnt sweet!  Theres a lot of wood or vegetable going on with this one, but its tasting better than another bottle from the same batch did a year ago.

Tasted on 7/30/11 from a 750mL capped bottle purchased at Archer Liquors a while ago, 2005 vintage.  Pours a cloudy, very dark garnet with a thick off-white head that slowly recedes to uneven lace with a decent collar.  The nose is sour with some balsamic vinegar, but dominated by aromas of intense vanilla and cinnamon oak.  The flavor is tart lemon, balsamic vinegar, and tons of oaky vanilla and cinnamon.  I mean TONS, this is almost like licking the inside of an oak barrel.  The body is medium with average carbonation, and a long, super oaky and very tannic finish.

sour cherries with a lashing of barnyard funk . Finishes like
a fine,blue cheese with lingering oaky notes.  Tastes like history.

Batch #13 to snifter. Pours a tea color with a foamy soapy off white head that fades to a film. Aroma is funk and citrus with cherries. Taste is bitter sour with a funk and woody cherries, pretty smooth and the sourness is very tolerable. Palate is medium and very fizzy with a chaulky dry finish. Easy drinking sour that is not over the top! Personnally enjoy the over the top sours, but this is very nice!
Flavor is sour and off flavored, like a gueze, with notes of cherries and oak.... Definitely a unique offering, but difficult to stratify between other good sours.... Enjoyable though
Bottle at the Davis Beer Shoppe. Really good sour, enjoyed it alot. Sour had more of a bite then other sours that I have had.
bottiglia allOpen. Buonissima, sour ale leggera come una carezza, da berne e riberne a non finire.

AROMA: Right off the bat, big sour cherries and black dirt - strong, musty, fruity -  very earthy; APPEARANCE: dark red-brown, murky, very little head and lacing; TASTE: Sour; PALATE: creamy, slightly spritzy, longish and a tad astringent, a tad.; OVERALL:  I have had better - not really. This really works for me.
Bottle in Toronto. This is a nice sour ale. Reminded me a lot of a lambic. Enjoyable and sour.
Pour is a hazy brown light head. Aroma is tart grapey peppery sour. Taste is light tart woody grapey earthy tart peppery. Good.

1pt 9.4oz bottle from greens in atlanta.  Batch #11 - 2009 - Bottle #3240.  Cola brown pour with small soapy head.  Aroma is musty cherry - sweet and sour.  Tastes are moderately tart mix of cherry, grape, green apple, oak, vanilla, leather, red wine and funk.  Light but long acidic sour in the dry finish.  Great balance.  Alcohol is covered well.  Very good.

It pours a reddish brown color into my tulip from the Bruery.  There is a small off white head but its gone pretty quickly.

Right as soon as I opened the bottle I got scents of freshly peeled Granny Smith apples.  When I put my nose into the glass for a smell there is a good funk with hints of cherries, grapes and plums.  I can pick up an ever slight bit of oak in there as well.

The taste has a nice tart flavor of the fruits.  It is a bit acidic in there too.  There is notes of vinegar and then finishes off with the oak that leaves a dry finish.

(Batch #12 - Bottle #755 - Snifter Glass)  Pours a nearly opaque brownish red color.  Has a sour aroma notes of sour cherries and sherry vinegar.  Medium sweetness, heavy sourness and very little bitterness. Has low to medium amount of carbonation and a pleasant dry sour finish.

Reddish Brown, either a nice lingering tan head, or no head whatsoever depending on which glass you look at... Immediate sour vinegar aroma upon uncapping... Lots of wood aroma, some dark fruit undertones, not bright sour apple or cherry like other sours, some funk, barnyard light, mustard... Lively, medium full bodied... Very fruity, has a distinct juice like quality, dry and not sweet woody finish, incredibly complex, flavors come out in the finish.. really dry finish... some cherry, lots of wood, the bordeaux explains the fruits without the sweetness.. The aroma is relatively pungent, but in now way compares to the flavor... amazing beer...

Pours reddish brown with a medium light tan head.  Aroma is very sour...sour cherries, vinegar, slightly boozy, woody, leather.  Flavor is also sour but more funky and spicy than expected...leathery and fruity but not sweet.  Mouthfeel is very light and slightly watery but the finish sets it off with a nice dry oaked mildly sour finish that lingers very pleasantly.  Excellent.

2010 bottle batch #12.  Pours a hazy reddish brown, with nice sustaining beige / grey bubbly head.  Aroma is lightly vinous, some fruity tones evoking cherry and berry, charred, sugary oak, and a hint of balsamic.  Flavor is complex, with a long, evolving finish.  There are touches of tart cherry, some orange, oak, soft cognac, a wide array of flavors.  The 8% is entirely hidden and it is actually kind of light in body, despite all the flavor it contains.  Overall an excellent sour, a work of art.

Light in flavor and only very slitly sour, this beer is malty and very refresh. Kind of like a deep saison sour. Some caramel, light raisins, biscuits, sour green grapes. Really smooth and drinkable. 2007 bottle, batch 7
On bottle 75cl. The acid and fruity flavours left me a very good memory in mind. Dark red colour, carbonated enough, medium level tartness body. So good.

Bottle. Batch 12, 2010, bottle 796 (Thanks Armin!)  Hazy brown pour, a little carbonation and a tart citrus aroma.  Flavor was slightly sour cherry and had a dirty barnyard aftertaste.  Unique and enjoyable.

[Batch 12 2010] shared by Armin. Thanks! Pours hazy reddish brown with a large beige head. Aroma is light fruity and red wine funkiness, moderate acetic, light rotten fruit. Flavor is moderately sour, light acetic, quite fruity, lightly bitter, light oak.

Bottle. Batch 12, 2010, bottle 796. Pours. Murky reddish mahagony color with a light white head. Cherry, acetone, and slight oak, ligh mouthfeel with carbonation. Sweet and tart start with a nice fruitiness to it. Not overly sour by any means. Ends with a slight tartness with a little bitterness. Overall, not bad but a little sweet.

Batch 12, 2010, bottle number 796.  Pours hazy reddish brown with barely off white head.  Aroma has notes of funk, horseblanket, lemon, sour cherry, with a touch of biscuit.  Taste is nice brett funk, with some nice lacto sour, with a nice dry, slightly bitter funk with a dry finish.

Bottle @ home. Dark maroon appearance with a reddish cream colored head. Sour, lactic, woody, raspberry, cherry, a touch dusty nose. Mild to moderate sourness, lactic, acetic, medium woodiness, cherry, raspberry, strawberry flavor. Acetic notes are stronger on the finish. Mild puckering, sour dark berry aftertaste. Nice sour that actually isnt that hard to find.
Slightly murky reddish color. Solid sour notes, rich and vibrant . Very interguing sour, reminds me of a complex rodenbach.
Excellent. A really well-done sour. Big bottle at Lincoln Wines. Nice complexity of sour, wood, a bit of sweetness, and a dry finish. Yum.
Very tart and fruity.  Acidic and fruity flavors.  Sour and fruity aromas.  Overall a very very good sour.

Sample at the Sour Village / CCB Tasting on 05/20/2011. Thanks to Moggman for sharing 2010 bottle #1890 (batch 12). The beer is a rich mahogany color with a medium thin off-white head that recedes quickly to an outer ring. Aroma of barnyard funk and fruit. Medium body with a moderately sour fruit character and touches of malt, yeast and earth. The finish is fruity with a lingering tartness left behind. Solid all around.

2010 bottle #1890 of batch 12 shared by Moggman. Pours red with a medium tan head. Aroma of funk and farts along with sourness and tart fruit that make it well worth the farts. Sour fruit flavor with a nice peppery character before a tart fruit finish.

750ml bottle from IPB.
Appearance : Clear amber with a small head.

Aroma : Awesome sour fruits with light funk and brett. Great cherries, nice tartness. Nice barnyard. Not very acidic not too vinous. Dirty at will.

Taste : Great cherries, nice sourness. Nice brett and funk. Barnyard with a nice tartness. Same as nose, not too acidic nor vinous.

Overall : Wow really impressive. Im usually not such a fan of flemish sours but I think this is a rather "soft" one if I may say. Not very lactic nor acetic. Quite drinkable for the style. Nice brett and barnyard with awesome fruity profile. Ill have this again.

Thought this was a wine for a second, in the beer section of the LCBO. Nope, its simply a sour ale in a dark green wine bottle with some plastic around the cap and the content looking really dark. Pours a clean copper-amber colour with a big frothy off-white head that has decent retention and thick foamy lacing. Nice active carbonation of medium-size bubbles becoming smaller and smaller as it goes. Aromas of red apples, cherries, with some notes of sourness and tartiness. Quite a sour taste at first. Then fruity with some currant, cherries ending quickly with a little malt. The alcohol is totally hidden and the mouthfeel a bit thin. Nonetheless, refreshing at room temperature. A decent Flemish sour from Italy, which I was not expecting to be as good. Just lacking a longer finish, but gets better as it breathes, and gets hazy near the last pour.

Pours a murky hazy mahogany colour with a thin white cap, good retention. The aroma is sour grapes, those green sour apple suckers, new belt leather, unfinished basement, young red wine, and yeast. The flavour is insanely complex, a thesaurus and a dictionary couldnt do it justice, 
my Neanderthal notes go something like, it starts out with a warheads sourness which fades away into a sort of musty, leathery, something or other, ends on mingled together notes of red wine, sour grapes, currents, and some other stuff.....the mouth feel is . . . foamy.
Ive never been big on the sour ales, but i rather enjoyed this.

Bottle shared with some friends at Coffee District. Dark reddish color with a thin head. Aroma has a good sour fruity funk to it. Flavor is sour, of course, with a possible vinegar touch, but mostly cherries come through on this one. A really enjoyable sour.
Bottle. Dark brownish purple color. Little head. Smells of grapes, berries and sugar. Taste the same with some bread and molasses. Really fine example

750 mL bottle bought and split with some friends. 2007 vintage. Reddish almost purple color with fast fading head. A warm color. The aroma was a apple cider with maybe some wine and just a little oak. The tastes starts out a little sweet like wine in the front but that full on sour builds tot he back for a nice smack of the lips. Pretty complex and very much gives the impression of a tart wine, grape juice and apple notes are prominent.

750 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a reddish amber colour with moderate-sized off-white head.  Aromas of sour apple and cherries, with some yeast and wood.  Flavour is acidic, sour fruit (cherry, apple, lemon and grape) with a subtle oakiness.  Quite dry.  Alcohol is quite hidden.  Impressive.

Bottle 2009 .... Great color deep amber brown pour light reddish tint light beige head light carbonation ... aroma of berries, oak and sour with light barnyard ..... taste is tart and sour with berries, oak, light barnyard and acidic with light wine flavor as well ..... finishes dry oaky and sour ... well done

(bottle) A chestnut body riddled with bubbles, and a big tan head. A sour aroma with notes of wood, grape, berries, and wine. Medium body, soft with carbonation. Flavor is wonderfully sour, and also starts out sweet before drying up quickly. Some cherry flavor, and I cannot seem to dismiss a little grape soda feeling, but I dont mean that negatively. Finish is quite dry. Complex but delicate. And tasty.

My first sour so its a little hard to judge.  Pours a mid-brown with solid head.  Liquid is hazy to the point of opacity.  Unmistakable aroma of Strongbow Cider when the bottle is opened.  The sour apple gets backed up by a bit of sour cherry.  Taste is sour, sour, puckery sour.  Long sour finish.

pours a hazy light brown with a decent beige head, some lacing and a decent retention. aroma is oak, cherries, acidic. taste is about the same along with a very light belgium yeast and spices profile. long acidic pungent finish. somewhat watery and very lightly hopped. good. not overwhelmed.

(bottle - 750 ml - 2006 vintage) Copper pour with a very small amount of off-white head. Sour and tart aroma with nice funky and earthy hints as well as some mild fruit. Flavor is tart and sour at the start that moves to a damp and funky middle with a very nice and lingering tart finish. Really smooth.

Pour ruby golden orange with white head. Aroma barnyard funk, cherry, oak, sour. Taste funk, sour, vinegar, barnyard, sour cheese, oak. MF prickly tangy very dry medium body. Overall very good sour quite tasty and happy this was readily available in Ontario.
This is a fantastic beer. Aromas of not quite ripe cherry, or maybe cranberry. Tart, but not overpowering. A classic.

I had this from a 750ml bottle, 2009 batch #11, bottle # 876...The beer pours a dark mahogany, light tan head, ok lacing...The aroma is light a little sour and vinegar, same with the taste but this beer is severly lacking to other great flanders. Lightly tart but not enough punch or vinegar. Really kind of boring and disappointing. Maybe a good flanders red for the beginner.
Bottle...  2007 Batch 9 poured a ruby/brown with a beige head.  Lactic yeast that lent towards dark fruits, especially cherries with a big tart finish..

750 ml bottle. Batch #12-Vintage 2010. Bottle# 2385. A reddish brown beer. The aroma is very fruity with lots of berries, balsamic vinegar and acidic. The taste is an interesting mix of fruit with some vinegar. Kind of like strawberries with balsamic vinegar. Very refreshing. I really like its fruitiness and very strawberry taste. This is a nice sour. This seems like it would pair well with strawberries and balsamic vinegar with mascarpone cheese.

Pours a light brown with a generous white head that diminishes quickly.
Enticing wet straw, barnyard smell that covers the aroma of rotting cherries. I used to pick cherries in Michigan as a kid and this brings me right back to sitting in those trees and eating Montmorency cherries until my mouth hurt. 
A bitter sourness that clings to your mouth long after you sip and leaves you sucking your teeth.
Paired with dinner this beer shined with sauteed lemon asparagus and chicken Parmesan. The asparagus brought the fruit forward, quelling the acidity to a pleasant bite.
This beer can stand up with the best of them from Belgium.
Incredible. Bitter, wine-like, sour, very enjoyable throughout. You need to be fairly knowledgeable to accept this as a good beer in North America.

Batch 8 from 2007.  Pours a fairly dark but largely transparent red with a small white head.  Sediment and a relatively lively carbonation are apparent on the pour.  Nose is a bit of vinegar and red wine; nice, but perhaps not quite as strong as you get from some similar sours.    The flavor is sour with some twangy vinegar funk and a bit of candied sweetness on the tale end.  Honestly, Id prefer something with a bit more sourness, as it isnt quite as biting as you can find elsewhere in the style.  Perhaps I waited a bit too long to drink this for my taste.  Also, the mouthfeel is a bit light for me.  The carbonation seems to fade relatively quickly, and youre left with a bit of a thin consistency.  Still, a solid offering that Im glad I tried, even if, in the future, Ill continue to spend half as much for Rodenbachs Grand Cru.

Thanks bro!  Translucent brown to amber with a pale white head.  Nose has some vinous and sour notes.  Refreshingly fruity (grape) with some lemon acidity.  Bit of a bite, with thick and juicy mouthfeel.  I wish I could taste more of the cognac barrel, but this is still an interesting and complex beer.
This one is very nice, it pours light head, the aroma is nice and it really tastes a sour, you can taste that, it is rather enjoyable, I would have this again

Bottle. The bottle was really well carbed as I barely touched the cap and you could hear the gas escaping. Pours slightly hazy dark brown with little head that fades quickly. Very floral with acetic notes in the aroma. Not as sour as you would expect which hides the alcohol perfectly. Im glad I bought more than one bottle because this beer was fantastic.

Murky, rusty brown with a small but sturdy beige head.  The tart aroma has lots of ripe fruit and berries.  The flavour is harder to describe.  Tart fruit.  Not sweet at all.  A metallic note.  Grape skin and sour cherries.  A little oak and cognac from the barrels.  No alcohol.  Fantastically dry.  Body is not big, but Im not educated enough to know whether this is a style thing.  I like it, though.

Bottle from the LCBO. Appearance: Gorgeous brown/red with a decent white head. Aroma: Good sour aroma (not knock your socks off sour but nice). Berries, yeast, rhubarb and cherries, Flavour: Lovely tangy sour at first, cherry and rhubarb again, lots of yeast, quite nicely carbonated, tingles the palate, decent lemon finish. Alcohol barely evident, lovely.

Appearance: plum and grape skins under an off-white khaki collar. No head. Clean and acidic even in appearance.

Nose: woody with a bit of horse and farm in the back. Eyes tickle/water from acidic fusels. Grows more funk as warms up with a nice addition of old leather freshly oiled. Grape and plum skins, hold the flesh please. Mustiness dominates the back.

Palate: grabs middle of tongue and doesnt let go, already drying from quaff numero uno. Plums and grape skins lead into wood, leather, and must which finish with the fruity remains of stems and skins. Quaff and repeat. Nice clean mouthfeel which leaves sides of cheeks tingling. Little on the breath, but grows more earthen the further along we venture together. Lovely balance.

Final Thoughts: Id hear numerous good things about this beer which I am quite pleased to say lived up to every bit of its hype. Further proof that Italy cares as much about the gourmand burgundian welfare of their beer as they do their wine and food.

Batch 8-THANK YOU DOUG! I liked this beer. Oh man, I liked this beer. Poured brown with a thin head. There was a huge fruit nose with some toasty malts lingering in the background. The acidity made my spidey senses (aka nose hairs) tingle. The taste was sweet bready malts and a touch acidic, but finished really dry. This beer is completely brilliant! On a scale of 1-A+ it gets a "heeeeeeey, alllllllright."

Bottle, 2009 vintage, batch #11. Red pour, with an orangey brown oxidation tint with a pinkish white ring.  Aroma is very woody, grassy, earthy with subtle cherry notes. Taste is very earthy as well, tobacco, more cherries present, not so sour but a lot of barrel character, quite wild. Palate is dry with a slightly sweet finish, almost flat. Alcohol is relatively well hidden.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2011 I was prepared for a sour bomb, very mild sourness. Nose is of a watered down rodenbach. All flavors are subtle, i can see the appeal here. Alcohol very hidden. A little pricey for what you get, rodenbach is better value.

2008 Bottle; Batch 10 - Pour is dark brown, amber highlights with a modest beige head. Aromas are toasted oak notes, cherry pits, and a slight yeasty feel. The tart, acetic element was certainly up front on this brew, but it dissipates into this funky cherry toasted oak brew that becomes quite palatable. I feel like this bottle lost a bit of something honestly. And this was bottle #2 - a 2009 batch was hideously bad (ashtray). So bad that I went out of my way to find another bottle just to get that memory out of my head. Anyway - all in all, a good experience

Bottle of the 2007, batch 8, bottle 1095.  Pours a clear ruby with some brown highlights and a large dirty beige head.  Mouthwatering aromas, soft wood, a touch of sweet balsamic vinegar, barnyard  funk, slow acid.  Gorgeous.  Subtle flavors, very gentle and a lot more subdued than I was expecting.  Not weak per se, but definitely a more delicate beer than initial aromas hint at.  Light acid, a soft sweetness, very light acid and a touch of tannins.  Finishes with some lingering lactic acid, very delicate and tangy.  Gorgeous stuff.

750ml bottle shared by Doug, thanks man 
Appearance: Hazy brown with a small off-white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Sour fruits and woody 
Taste: Sour fruits, vanilla, woody with a dry finish 
Nice.

750 ml bottle acquired via trade. Batch 8, bottle 1804, 2007 edition, three or four years old. Pours a cloudy brown with a whispy off-white head of medium size. A fruity woody nose, oak for sure, sweet berries. The flavor is very good; rich lively sourness, woody, lots of dark and sour fruit, does the cognac come into play perhaps? A smooth sour brown ale done very well. Italy has a lot of good brewing going one for sure.

From the rare beer club. Sampled from a 750 ml bottle this beer poured a red-brown color with a huge foamy tan head that lingered and produced good lacing. The aroma was sour and very odd with notes of olive, fig and molasses. The flavor was a craptastic mix of tart, sour, olive, chalk, red wine, red meat, faint grapefruit and bile. The finish was long, tart and sour with wood, chalk and cherry pits lingering. Medium body. Complex but not at all in a good way. Rather a disgustingly vile steaming pile of sour crap.

Bottle. Murky dark brown color with light tan hints around the edges.  Sour fruit and oak aromas, but a bit muted.  Lacto-sourness, woody, and some cherries all make it into the flavor.  Thinner body with nice carbonation.  Very tart finish, and really refreshing.  Not an overly puckinger sour, but really lovely.

15-01-11 Bouteille 750ml batch 2007: Belle apparence entre le vin rosée et le vin rouge. Très légère effervescence et petite mousse blanche qui reste. Arômes sapparentant a ceux dune gueuze (ce qui explique ma cote basse), avec des notes très vineuses de fruits rouge et de barrique. Moyennement sucrée (on sen aperçoit suite au dépot de sucre sur les lèvres), avec une petite amertume et des notes très surette, mais beaucoup plus balancée que la Rodenbach Grand Cru. Boisée, corps de léger a moyen, se boit très facilement et serait parfait pour une chaude journée dété. Sa texture est plutôt vineuse et est asser carbonisée. La finale est douce et nous rappel un léger vin rouge avec des notes surette.

Not what I expected.  Funky smell of  fermented peaches on the ground in an orchard.  When held up to the light, the colour reminds me of old pears.  First impression on tasting is of vinegar, soured cherries, and rotted wood.  Curious on the palate as it is tingly and spritzy.  After the initial shock, I am finding complexity and a pleasant mix of different sours.  Somewhat thin on the tongue, but what a dry finish.  Thanks Peggy and Mitch for an interesting birthday present.

2006 bottle drank at 4 years.  Solid amber color with no carbonation left.  Aroma of sour cherries, funked fruit, and a light touch of funk in and of itself.  Flavors have blended together well, with the oaked sour note in plumland definitely reigning champion.  Pleasant and not too overwhelming dry finish that lingers politely.  Kept well!

03/10 0.75 l bottle, courtesy of Marko, huge thanks for sharing! It was a bottle from 2006. It poured hazy muddy reddish to brown body with medium sized head. Simply sour aroma, similar to wild yeasts in lambics. Vinegar, wild yeast flavor, just as simple as the nose suggests. Some slight fruit flavors may be present, like sour cherry or peach. Thinner body,but as of the sourness it had longer, though simple finish. Just to note, alcohol is not felt at all. Expected so much more from this one, no matter its an aged bottle, it was very simple and just an average sour ale.

Batch 9. Sick with bronchitis and I am in need of some lactobacillius to balance out my antibiotics. Pours a light mahogany color with a large creamy tope head. Notes of malt vinegar, celery, old fruit, gamey stew, and musty basement. Long finish with a somewhat high level of carbonation.
bottle, nice looking beer in the glass, rusty orange with creamy soapy tan foam, aroma is tart, woody cherries, flavor of  soft sour dried cherries, woody, earthy, nice funk finish

09 bottle:pours a deep red brown with a reasonable bubbly head.notes of fermented fruit,dates,cider,ginger.medium mouthfeel and carbonation.the oak barrels add a bit of depth behind the sourness.Im warming to this beer.

Bottled 750ml. -Courtesy of Marko, shared with him and heavy (thanks!).
2006 version. Unclear dark red coloured, small off-white head, sour cherries in the nose. More of the same in the taste; sour cherries (but not so sour as Ive expected), moderate fruity and caramel. Hint of wood and berries in rather acidic finish. Nice one.
Pours an amber red color with a white soapy head.  Has an aroma of vinegar and funk.  Has a sweet tarty taste with yeast notes.  Bit of funk on the finish.  Decent.

OK, so whats all the rage about sour beers? I had to find out with this- supposedly one of the best. $18 for a 2006 vintage bottle. A dead-flat medium amber color. Tart, musty aromas. Flavors are complex. Some tart sweetness, oak, vanilla and smoky leather notes. Thin watery mouthfeel. Not overly tart or sweet. Tangy finish. ABV is very well masked. However, I dont think Ill be jumping up and down over this style anytime soon.
10/9/10.  Sweet and slightly sour aroma with definite peanut character... Hmmm.  More sour flavor with sweet caramel peanut butter flavor as well.  Not bad!

2006 version, courtesy of Alex (fiulijn), enormous thanks! Shared with heavy and ogivlado. Poured a murky dark red body with a small white head that went away at a medium pace. Sweet cherryish, slightly acidic taste, soft, light, soft, "wild", with some maltiness. The sourish taste brings out the cherry again, fine and fruity, with just perfect acidity, not too strong, not too light. Not as complex as I expected it to be but a lovely beer in any case, perfectly balanced.
From a bottle poured a dark amber color with a good amount of head.  Nice tart malty flavor with a quick finish.
pours deep reddish brown. thin head. Aroma is sour withnotes of dark fruits. Flavour is very nice. bold and sour with flavours of dark fruits and cherries. malty with subtle caramel notes. nice brew.

aroma is deep woody sweet and sour--mix of citrus-sour and vinegar-sour.
it pours light brown and is almost clear, with a foamy yellowish head.
flavor is also sweet and sour, mild but with a nice tart finish. very drinkable, alcohol is barely discernible, with medium slick body and low carbonation.
750 shared thanks to Jarrett. Batch 9 2007 bottle. Red and brown in color. Brown sour ale. Lots of body and well balanced tart. Very nice.

this is my 4th attempt at this beer. the previous three had been either dead flat or off. 2006 vintage with carbonation courtesy of cbk on 6/27/2010.

hazy cherry juice tinted brown with an off white head.

dusty aroma... notes of grapes, tart cherries, vanilla, wood and cinnamon.

the flavor is the same... very mineral-y/slate. its not overly tart.. more like watered down balsamic.

medium bodied with some residual malt richness. it is refreshing but a little dull on the tongue. 8/4/7/3/16/3.8
bottle 2008. Pours a clear brown with no head. Aroma of bourbon and cherries. Flavor of light tartness and lots of hard alcohol. I dont dig the sour cherries much, but it wasnt bad.

Bottle from Batch 8, 2007.  

A: The pour is a fairly typical dark amber color with plenty of brown to it. The head is somewhat mild in volume and off-white in color.

M: Quite fruity for a Flanders red ale. Lots of cherries, green apples, and a bit of lemon. Plenty of oak, a hint of vinegar, and some light sweetness.

D: A bit lighter in flavor than I would have expected. The fruitiness translates well to the flavor, as do the vinegar and oakiness. There is, however, a bit of a metallic flavor at times.

M: The body seems a bit thin, but for a sour beer it is a bit more forgivable. Moderate and tinging carbonation.

D: Pretty easy beer to drink, but not all that impressive. Maybe a more current vintage would change things a bit.

Bottle 2007 vintage - Pours rosy mahogany with a small white head. Light plastic and earthy Brett on the nose, some oak notes, and some balsamic vinegar. Smells balanced and smooth, but still has a decent amount of funk. Cherries and oak dominate the taste, thought its fairly dry and lightly puckering on the finish. Light and watery, I could easily sip a full pint of this, slowly and contemplatively. Really, really liked this one.

Bottle. 2005 Vintage. Pours a hazy pale orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity woody sour tart aroma. Smooth fruity sour tart woody flavor. Has a fruity sour tart finish with hints of wood in the aftertaste.
fruity sourness that pours a cloudy purblish red brown.  Medium sweetness with a heavy sourness.  Very light on the tongue.  A beautiful, interesting sour ale.

Dark red-amber with scant, off-white, head / Refined, sour, nose of distilled cherries and oak / Medium body, tart with malts, hops, and carbonation, and with good balance and finish / Flavors of aged, fermented cherries & dark berries, licorice, herbs, cinnamon, and oak / Very nice.
Cloudy copper with a lasting off-white head. Oaky aroma with coconut and vanilla, plus a hint of popcorn. Dry and tart, with a vineous fruit/berry  note. Oak flavour and tannin in the finish.

2005 vintage from Archer Liquors. Finally got around to buy this brew. Hazy mahogany body with fine particles and a persistent, uniform tight beige head,. Surprized this still held up well, lots of carbonation. Aroma is of quality fruit vinegar, toasted vanilla, overripe sour cherries, and bright red wine. Mostly dry flavor of cherries, young figs, and soft, aged vinegar. Just enough residual sugar to make this palatable and pleasing on the tongue.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2010 Bottle, at Jimmys no. 43 during the Lovullo Sour Tasting Session. Pours a dark, red-brown with a slight, white film. Tart, sour aroma with mild fruit and wood. Flavor is extremely puckering and very sour. Plenty of Brett and lactic acids. Mild sweetness. Some booze, especially in the finish. Light woodiness throughout. Some licorice notes. Pretty nice.

Draft  & Bottle @ Open Baladin, Rome. Pours unclear dark amber with a small creamy white head and lacings.Nose is vinegar, oak , berries and a bit of marzipan. Very dry and fruity tart flavor. Refreshing. Nice one

Dark brown pour with a one finger white frothy head. Aroma holds a lot of salt water, a touch of sour cherry, not a whole lot else. Not as complex as I would have expected, and really just smells like the beach. Flavor is much more interesting, with the salt giving way to big notes of oak, booze, liqueur, and cherry. Palate is tart and extremely dry. Not my best rating, but this is a pretty tasty sour ale on the whole.
